text: - Welcome to this Fireside Chat.
I'm Shaown Nandi,

Head of Technology for
Global Sales at AWS.
And I have with me Eddie from Workday
who heads AI engineering.

Eddie, tell us a little
bit about what you do.
- Sure. My name's Eddie Raffaele.
I head up AI engineering for Workday.

Our team is responsible for
building all of the features,

models, and products that
our customers use every day
across our HCM and FIN products.
- Very awesome.
So like, I was a Workday customer

back when I was a CIO, and
it was a couple years back,
and I used to imagine all these things
that would be possible.
And now it seems like they sort of are.

I know you've been putting in
AI and generative AI features.

Like what's been changing
the last few years?
What sort of new things are happening?

- Yeah, it's been really
interesting to watch the evolution.

What we saw a few years
ago was a lot of concern
or trepidation around making sure we know
exactly where AI is being used,

customers not being sure about
how many features to turn on.

And now today, tremendous
growth and appetite.
We want AI everywhere.

We really want it to help
streamline our business,
optimize our business processes,
help us make better decisions faster
with the right information.
So context has been really,
really important and surfacing that up.

Workday sits on this
treasure trove of information

around all of the things that
matter most to your business,
your people and finance data.
And so letting you leverage that every day

using machine learning and
AI is the number one driver
for where we spend our time
in product development at Workday.
- I love it.

So like I get that customers
are more open and willing.

The last two years have
been sort of game-changing

in terms of people's mental
models and their openness
and some nervousness in some cases.
What sort of things have been unlocked
since generative AI became more realistic?

Are there new concepts that
you didn't attack before

with just sort of classic
AI and machine models,
sorry, machine learning?

- Yeah, what we look at is
where are you spending your time
doing repetitive tasks, for example.

A really good example is
creating a job description.

People are creating
thousands and thousands

and thousands of them in
Workday every single day.
And you might start from a blank page,
and it would take you at least an hour
to write a really good job description.
Using generative AI,

we can actually make that
happen in seconds for you.
You make the final edits
and what we let you do is spend your time
bringing the expertise for the rec
that you're trying to create,
do that small adjustment, get it posted,
and you're done in minutes as opposed
to spending an hour starting from scratch.
- Eddie, that's really interesting.
So accelerating job descriptions,
like I will tell you as a people leader,

every time I have to write a
JD, I get a little paralyzed.
I'm like, "I got to make this perfect"

and end up sitting on it for
a week, which is terrible.

So that sounds like a
pretty amazing feature.

How are customers responding
to features like this?
- Yeah, we've got hundreds of customers
using that feature today,
generating thousands of job descriptions.
And what's really interesting is the data
and telemetry we're able to capture.

So for example, does
generating a job description
result in applicants applying faster,
closing the requisition faster,

and that frees up time for
the entire organization

to be more productive with
the rest of their time.
- So are you putting the outputs

into some like information
reports, et cetera,
to tell folks what's happening?

- Yeah, Workday recruiting
gives you information

on how long it takes
to close a requisition.
We track telemetry on, for example,
how many requisitions are created,
are they using the generative feature,
are they modifying that?

We use that to retrain models
to try to improve accuracy

and be able to capture the
tone of an organization.

The way your company writes
a job description for example
might be very different than another one.
We want to represent that
for you when we generate content for you.
- I love it.

So when you're thinking
about building features
like this one, different features,

what's your mental model, like
how did you engage with AWS

and what sort of tech
stacks do you imagine here

to like support sort of I guess
the broad range of features
you can be building in the future?
- We make extensive use of AWS services.

Everything from how we move
data, how we compute data,

do the data engineering, then
do the model experimentation,

and then get that deployed
and running across the world.

So we run in multiple
regions all on AWS hardware,

and it's been a really
great partnership where

it's that ecosystem or
the breadth of services

that AWS offers that make a
big difference in our ability
to get to market faster.
- And are you generally building,
are you starting with SageMaker?
What's your mental model there?

- Yeah, we'll start with
more managed services,

things like SageMaker to do
really rapid experimentation.
And where we need to,

we'll run our services from
the ground up on AWS compute.

So for example, we might
run array-based array

on EKS inference platform,
that all runs on AWS,
but it lets us deploy that

and auto-scale that in
our different regions.
And that comes after we do experimentation
using something like SageMaker
where we can try different models quickly.

- So use SageMaker to
sort of get started fast,

and then you might go and
deploy a custom stack if needed
and use leverage for orchestration,
leverage EKS for orchestration, et cetera.

- Exactly, it's kind of
that Swiss Army knife

of letting us try lots of
different things quickly

and AWS having a lot of
different solutions available
for us out of the box.
- I love it.

And what are you finding
from model perspective?
Are you letting sort of one model
be the answer in every case?

Are there different sizes
and types of models?
- We use a mix and match approach.
So we're trying to use the smallest model
that yields the best results,

we do that for a number
of different reasons.

One is of course latency,
performance, cost.

We're also trying to
make sure that we're able
to protect our customer's data.
So doing things like using RAG

to provide security over
the data that's being served

to customers and being
able to retrain the model

to capture the changes that
happen in your environment.
So by using smaller models,
we're able to train more often,

we're able to provide
faster response times
that are more accurate for the customer.

- And when you have an
idea for like a feature
or a function you want to build,

what's sort of your mental
model for engineering?
Like tell me about, you know,
is there a proof of concept process,

or you mentioned rapid
experimentation with SageMaker.

How does that sort of design
flow work for your teams?

- Yeah, so we try to look at
what metrics do we care about?
Are we trying to optimize how fast a user
is able to get something done?
Are we trying to improve the experience?
Are we trying to improve just quality?

What are the metrics that
we're trying to target?

And then how quickly can we
spin up a proof of concept?
In machine learning,

it's easy to have an
idea and maybe the data
doesn't back it up

or you're unable to train
a model that effectively

gets you the results
that you're looking for.
And so we'll try to really quickly get

to that prototype stage
using either synthetic data

or some of our test data
using the AWS services
and prove out, yes, this is viable.

And then we'll go into
the production process.
- And so you're seeing more and more
of these features go to production
because I know that's a question a lot
of your peer customers have had,
like how much actually goes to production,
how hard is it to get to production?

When does experimentation sort
of end and production begin?
- Yeah, so what we do with our customers
is involve them really early.

So we try to get feedback from
a select group of customers,
we invite them to come participate
in our early access programs.
We've got even kind of earlier preview

or beta features that we
let customers experience,

and that gives us a lot
of really valuable data
on we actually need it to work like this
and make those really small adjustments
that are in any product life cycle
before it gets out to GA

where any of our customers
can just turn it on
and start using it.

- I love it, and tell me
about like challenges,
like what have been some of the obstacles

in the way of sort of building
out these new capabilities?
- Software's supposed to be cheap.

You build it once and
you copy and paste it
and it scales really quickly.
Machine learning is expensive to build,

expensive to scale, and
that's been a challenge.
So how do we do things like control cost,
protect our customer's data,

scale that up and make it
available to customers,
the never ending set of challenges there.

And so we've tried a number
of different techniques there

largely in partnership
with our friends at AWS

and making sure that we're
able to target smaller models.

So using things like
distillation or quantization

to drive smaller models,
drive performance and cost,
drive performance up and cost down,

and combining those
techniques to try to make
kind of a holistic solution
that works best for our customers.

- And tell us how you've
been leveraging Bedrock.
What's been your impression so far?

- Yeah, Bedrock's been
a great place for us

to not have to worry about how
to manage all of the models
or get new models online.

Everything is kind of just
there for us out of the gate.

And so what our engineers
are able to do is say,
"Okay, we're going to start a new POC."

Which models should we
quickly go and evaluate?

Is it something new like Nova
that AWS recently announced,
or should we use something from Meta
in the Llama family of models

or some of the partner
models that are available?

- Yeah, I know. I love
having so much model choice.

How do your teams get savvy
about which model to use when?
Obviously you mentioned experimentation,
but is there like an education curve

where they use certain tool
sets to benchmark and measure?

- Yeah, we've got a model
evaluation framework,

we do tend to kind of go
back to the same models
that have yielded good results for us.
And I think there's just a learning curve
on what are you trying to achieve.

Is it long form text, is
it trying to generate code,

what's the modality of the
model that you're trying to,
or the modality of the feature
that you're trying to invoke.

There's such a plethora of
models it feels like every week

there's a new one announced
and so it's impossible
to keep up and try every single feature
with every single model.

So you need to kind of
have some instinct around
what yields the best results.
- And when you build with Bedrock,
have you had any thoughts on the ability
to sort of switch between models over time
as you've launched features and functions?

Have you done much experimentation
or thinking around that?
- Yeah, we'll look and say,
"Okay, this feature's performing at X, Y,
or Z percentage of accuracy,

and do we want to invest
time to improve that?"

And improving that could
be using the existing model
and fine-tuning that potentially,
looking at a new version of the model,

looking at an entirely different
provider for a feature.
We'll also look at things like
what language does this need to support

and different models
support different localities
or support different languages.

And we evaluate all of that
on a per feature basis.
- And have you started looking at things
from an agentic perspective yet?

Is that coming or already
happening for you?

- Yeah, we're spending a lot
of time like everybody else
thinking about agents and evaluating

how can we help our customers
get things done faster?

Agents are a great way for
us to be able to think about
where can we automate things,

where can we put the power
of these language models,

the ability to orchestrate
these complex agent flows
that take advantage of all the data

that sits in Workday for
you to be able to just say,

"Here's what I need done,
go and execute that for me."
- Absolutely, absolutely.

And when I think about
features and functions coming,
what do you have in mind for the future?

What sort of things are you
sort of dreaming about doing,
both sort of technically and functionally,

you can sort of go in
any direction with that.
- What we're really focused on right now
is looking at where are the opportunities
to accelerate your business,

how can we transform the
way your business works?

As organizations get bigger,
they get more complicated.

What Workday's trying
to do is drive that down
so that you're able to be more effective

with the people and technology
and resources that you've got
and help you get things done faster.
I want you to be able to get into Workday,

do what you need to do, and
get out to run your business.

And I know that that's getting
more and more complicated.
And so what we're looking at with agents
is how can we simplify that down
and let you be able to be more efficient?

- Oh, I love that. That's
really interesting.
Just going back a second,

you think about all these
features and functions
you're building that are AI-powered.
How do you think about them as a provider
to so many types of customers on
where they fit into your mental model

on like how customer sort
of operates with you?
Are they new SKUs?

Do they tend to be features
that just get bake in?

Like how do you deal with
the return on investment
for these features for Workday?
- Both, so we always continue
to invest in our existing products,

and you can see that in
things like recruiting,

where there's features like
job description generation,

we help you create things
like help articles.

And what we don't do is say,
"Look, here's a feature.
It just helps you generate articles."
What we look at is given a document,

can we create the FAQ that's
available to the workforce,
the talking points for a manager,
what employees might care about.

And so we know that
there's different audiences

for all of the pieces
that we might generate.
And so we put that all into the product.
And then of course we're thinking about
kind of ground up product development,
SKUs that were not possible previously
all built kind of in an AI first way.
- So we talked about how

some customers are looking
and seeing these bills
and costs for generative AI
and they seem potentially very big.
What are you seeing?

How are you seeing those
costs change as you do things?
You mentioned model distillation,
as you're using managed services,

what are you seeing
happening with the cost
of machine learning?

- I think there's an even
bigger cost to not doing it.
AI is definitely going to transform
and is transforming the industry.

Almost every industry is
going to see an impact
from artificial intelligence.
So doing nothing I think is going to have
a much higher cost in the long run.

The investments you make
today should pay off
in the ability to change the way

that your own products are
being used by customers.
- It's pretty impressive.
I think it's one of the powers
of being a software provider,
a SaaS provider like yourself
because you can sort of bring that value

to so many customers every
time you build something once.
So I'm curious about the future.
Like what are some of the things

that you're thinking about
over the next several years
that you could bring to customers?

What are some of the sort
of pie in the sky ideas
that suddenly feel plausible now
without giving away anything too secret?

- I think we're constantly
looking at the existing products

that we have and reinventing
those in an AI first way.

There's kind of that concept
of innovator's dilemma.

Do you continue doing
what you have been doing
versus starting from scratch

or looking at a completely
ground up way of
the way your product should be working.

And we ask ourselves
that on a regular basis.
When we're looking kind of on the medium
and long-term horizon,
certainly agents are a big part of that.

How can we have the
machine working for you
versus you working for the machine?

- I'd love to hear a bit
about your teams at Workday,

the engineering teams
and the product teams.
How have you helped keep them savvy

about all the advancements
and changes in AI
to help them imagineer what could be next?
- We do a couple of different things.

We make a lot of the
AWS services available
to our internal teams

through Workday's machine
learning platform.

And so that's been a great
partnership with the AWS team.

And we provide kind of
best in class examples
internally to try to foster ideas.
We run lots of hackathons,

we partner up with all of the
different development teams

inside of Workday to
try to get them thinking
about how AI could change their products,

and then enable them to
self-serve or run on their own.
- I love it. That's really interesting.

So what advice do you have
for other companies out there

that are trying to figure
out how to go and build
and deploy and use AI?
- My advice is to get into it.
The folks who I've seen lean into it
seem to be in a better spot.
You don't know what you don't know.
And so getting in there
and trying to experiment with things,

how can AI change the
way your products work,

get creative about how you're
applying the technology
into your own solutions.
Curiosity is a kind of a great trait
to have throughout this process.
- I love it.
And with all the expertise Workday has
on dealing with people,
I'd be curious about your perspective
on how you're retaining, attracting,
building all this great talent

that you must have to build
these features and products,

and how are some of the
managed services products
maybe making it a bit easier for you?

- I think on the retaining
people and talent,
it's really about making sure

that the engineers have
the best technology

at their fingertips and
making that available.

A big part of that has been
working with AWS to make sure

that they have the access
to the latest models,
access to things like SageMaker,
being able to use all of the data
that's available from within Workday
that our customers trust us to use
to train models for them,

keeping them engaged on
solving hard problems.

That's such a rewarding
experience day in and day out,

working on hard problems
that really make a difference
to people every day.
Workday's powering frontline workers,
people who depend on Workday to get paid,
to pay their bills.

And so for me, that resonates
as a motivating factor.
I think that actually resonates with a lot
of the folks in the organization,
and the work that you're doing every day

makes a real difference
in somebody's life.
- Oh no, that's really powerful.
I mean, I know for most technologists,
they want that hybrid of like working
with the latest and greatest,

but then seeing their work
have impact for people.
That's really exciting.
Great, well thank you for coming
and spending some time with us today.
I really appreciate it,

and I know everyone's going to
be excited to hear your story.

- Yeah, happy to be here.
Thank you for having me.
